Merge pull request #479 from tatsushid/fix/suppress-ipc-wsarecv-error

Suppress WSARecv error by case-insensitive match

Suppress WSARecv error by case-insensitive match

On Windows, Serf outputs a WSARecv error message every time when it
receives a client IPC request.

Its code seems to try to suppress such an error message but it just
matches "WSARecv" word against an error message though the actual one
only has a lower case "wsarecv" word in recent Go implementation.

This fixes it by comparing a lower cased error message with "wsarecv",
in other words, doing case-insensitive match.

Merge pull request #478 from lorenzosaino/serf-stats-coordinates-disabled

Fix Serf.Stats() panic when coordinates are disabled

Fix Serf.Stats() panic when coordinates are disabled

If the Serf agent is configured with coordinates disabled (i.e.
serf.Config.DisabledCoordinates = true), invoking Serf.Stats() causes a
segmentation fault. That's because in order to set the value of
"coordinate_resets" in the stats map, Serf.Stats() invokes
s.coordClient.Stats(), with s.coordClient being a nil pointer.

This commit fixes this issue by setting the value of "coordinate_resets"
in the stats map only if coordinates are enabled.

the _test suffix. As the testing package declares some global flags
using during tests, it's important to not import it in non-test
binaries, otherwise you will end-up with unwanted flags (like
-test.bench, -test.benchtime and -test.run).

(.*) so that the regex will act similar to how one would expect from a command
line tool.

It is not likely that someone would pass something like
-tag role=^(app|cache)-[0-9]+$ on the command line. More common patterns would
be things like -tag role=*web , or -tag active=* (to match any with the tag).

not expect something like -tag role=a to include nodes with a tag of role=cache.
In our previous implementation, this would still match due to the open-endedness
of the regular expression, and the MatchString() method. If a user really wants
to match all nodes with a tag containing the letter a, they would more likely do

interleaved calls, could expose potentially strange state updates.
Instead prefer to allow the change coalescing to be time skewed.
